@[Thiago] To make the dropdown menus in KATON more user-friendly, they should be modified so that the entire dropdown area is clickable, not just the arrow. This change should apply to both the user client and the admin interface by default. There can be exceptions for specific cases, such as when selecting a user from a list of 1000, where typing initial letters might be more practical. However, this exception should only apply to about 2% of all dropdowns.
For implementation, would it be possible to modify the dropdown definition globally within the Tailwind framework, instead of adjusting each dropdown individually throughout the system? This approach would ensure consistency and reduce the need for repetitive modifications.

ok, got it
I will update select component.

we can check the number of dropdown options in the dropdown component and decide whether to show dropdown or not

of course, it can be done globally
<https://trello.com/c/GYXSipx5/109-general-change-dropdown-menues-109>

@[Leticia] we need also a place in the user admin, where we show, from where the user came first time, but also with a history on the auction site. This gives us the possebility to see, how much it makes sence for example tospend money for Facebook advertisment etc...

@[Eric AKPLA] @[Christian Bielert] can we detect a user with a token or anything simular when he is on our website, even he is not logged in? If so, how long does this token exist? Can we store this user behavior in our DB, so we can see it in Admin?

I don’t think there is way to identify a user even he is not logged in. A token is issued to a user when he logged in only.

Of course we can make a feature to store in DB if user comes to our site from another site like advertisement urls…
It's technically possible, but of course it is some effort and complexity to implement.

Especially if you want to store it on the DB side, it means you need to introduce a new concept for a user who is not logged in. Then you need to think about how to connect this to a user when they register / log in. You need to consult with legal expert to ensure the technical implementation is done in compliance with GDPR. It is quite a large feature to do right.

You still haven't explained what the requirements are for the editor, so I can't answer.

1. We want to create the layout, decide if one column or two columns (in case of last: which is seen first on mobile)
2. We want to say which content type (text, image, link etc.) is in this column
3. We want to add the selected content (e.g. if image is selected, show upload function for image)
Every content and column can be exchanged in order
In my view then it's not a big difference to do it ourselves vs use unlayer. Because the requirements are not that complex, and integrating unlayer means we have to use their external API.

Hi @[Leticia]

within one site we would like to do auctions in future containing products of different categories and sub categories. E.g. One auction with 10 lots horses, 10 lots with riding accessoires, 10 lots with trucks.

The admin dashboard currently allows us to set different product categories and make their settings, attributes, layout etc. Good so far - but how now to process them in to auction and lot?

When creating an auction we currently have no option to define in there which product categories it contains, we just have this lot type included to define fees and terms. The question is if we just rename this and this is enough?

When adding now lots manually to an auction we currently have no option to match them to the auction I think. We just have the slug. So we need this I think?

Neither we ask - when adding the lot - of which category it is, so that the right layout mask and tabs appear in admin. I think we have to do that as I have no other idea on how the dashboard differentiates which lot creation setting to display? The one we have currently is very tailored towards horses.
@[Leticia] please when you come in, can you have a look at this? This is important to clarify ..

I think we can set it at a lot level. Then, we would have the system to detect which lots are added to the auction and add the necessary fields that those lots need at an auction level.

Do you think this is enough to cover the needs?

I think that at a lot level is a must. But we could also add at an auction level, and that would also filter which lots can be added to that auction. So if you set the auction as only horses, you cant add horse accessories to that auction. If you're uploading, it will show as invalid. If you're adding in the auction settings, it simplely won't show

For the auction settings we can do it in the section auf fees and terms and rename it as it is equivalent to the actual system. We need it at auction level as every product category might have its own terms and conditions

Yes on lot level it is a must. We differentiate two ways of adding lots. First by upload, which is mostly a complete auction collection of lots and second manually

If lots are added by upload the system should identify if there are product categories in the respective column that are not added to the auction settings (I think this is then a DEV task?) And by upload it gets the information which lot settings to display in admin

If lots are added manually it should ask to which auction ( a lot shall never be added without auction) and dependent on the auction selected it should ask which product category this lot is (and give for selection only those that are taken in auction settings)

Currently adding lots manually after the auction was already created and lots have been uploaded is a more complex thing which we would like to improve in the new system

@[Eric AKPLA] @[Christian Bielert] @[Leticia] @[Thiago] When we create a new auction, the correct approach would actually be to only display the parameters that are actually used in the specific auction. There are parameters that are necessary for an online auction but not for an OnLive auction. Can we not make the page dependent on whether an OnLive or an Online auction is being created?
Where we need to be careful is if an auction switches from an OnLive auction to an Online auction and vice versa. This scenario can occur. Then there would be settings for parameters that would either have to be deleted or at least muted. If it switches back, having them "muted" would make it easier because they could simply be reactivated. @[Romina True] had the idea today and i think this is for shure the right way to do so.
It's the right solution in principle. Can you please explain what does muted mean?

Mute" refers to a functionality where certain parameters or settings of an application are temporarily deactivated or hidden, without being permanently deleted. In the scenario where an auction switches from one type to another (e.g., from OnLive to Online or vice versa), muting parameters means these settings are no longer active or visible but remain stored in the system. Should the auction revert to its original type, the muted parameters can be easily and quickly reactivated without the need for reconfiguration or re-entry.
Maybe functionality by introducing a state management for each parameter, with states such as "active", "inactive", or "muted". When changing the auction type, relevant parameters would be adjusted according to their new context by changing their state. A muted parameter remains in the system and retains its original settings but is temporarily disregarded in both the application's user interface and functionalities.
But it is not a must. Its just an idea
Because sometimes organisation asking to change a online into a Onlive auction and the other way arround
I am wondering does it mean visible and disabled, or does it mean hidden.
At least we need to be shure that when the auction type is changed, parameters that was set before and just needed for the auction type before, dont influence anything
Im saying "Mute" because i know it from a sound studio. You can mute a channel :sweat_smile:
I just want to know, should the muted fields still be visible?
It means hidden and disabled
No
Ok. From a frontend viewpoint it's not an issue.
As if you change from onlive to online, you will not see the parameter no more
Regarding backend, it has to be programmed carefully to ensure the parameters are only used when the auction type is selected.
Yes exactly. That is the point
But we can also just delete the parameters that are not needed no more. Maybe this is more secure
And if they again want to swap, then they need to add them again. That would make most sence
And it is not so dangerous

Maybe it is better. Because imagine you put it to OnLive and put some values in. Then you go back to Online. Then 2 weeks later you put it back to OnLive. What if there is some configuration in there that you forgot about?

For example Online auction does not need prebid_start_time. so if the auction type is Online, that parameter has no effect and not used.

So if an auction was Onlive and prebid_start_time was set, and the auction is changed to Online, that parametter is hidden on the admin form page, and is not used its logic is not used.
If the auction is turned into Onlive the values for Onlive that was set before can be seen again….
What do you think @[Eric AKPLA] is it better to delete the values or not?
If there is some configuration in there that was forgoten, you can not save the auction
@[Simon Kohlenbrenner] Normally yes, you can save it. It is a valid configuration still. But if you forget about it, it may not make sense anymore for current setup.

No need to delete, by the auction type, we know the parameters needed. Other auction type parameters will not be used

Please @[Nasirou Wagana] what do you think about this getSchemas method? The issue I see is that the forms structure on the frontend won't necessarily match the data structure on the backend

<https://sporthorses24.com/developers/katon/-/merge_requests/278/diffs#118cdedc794e8c66f153db8f25c92cc8009acb17_0_30>

First, I think we want to make the Form component as lightweight as possible. The main idea behind the getSchema method is to extract it from the Component and manage it within the Model, potentially making it reusable. The right place for this function is normally inside the Model.

@[Nasirou Wagana] The problem is that models and forms are different concept. For example, we have a standalone form for logo URLs. But on the database model, logo URLs are just fields on the site model.
I got you. All the forms in Frontend won't necessarily match 100% to our Model. But we need to make sure to follow the Backend data structure when we are submitting data from Frontend.

Regarding optimization, on mobile right now we have the issue that DOM for full page is loaded on mobile, even though only a small part of the DOM is displayed / interactable. In the future we need to find a solution for this.

@[Leticia] Do you know good best practice for this? In particular, it is easy to lazy load components that aren't visible, but the issue is then layout shifts. We need a way to know the size of a component without loading the full DOM.
Isn't skeleton loading a good option?

I'm not sure, loading many skeletons for a long page could also be bad. In the start it could be enough to just show blank space. We can switch to skeleton as the user scrolls, the user will never see the blank space as we can use a buffer area
But whether we use blank space or skeleton, the issue is always knowing the size of the component without rendering it

I never got into the code side of skeleton, however, in terms of UI I see that's created a similar shape from the real content, it doesn't need to be the exact size. You still have to load the placeholder content, but it's quicker than the real content
small shift in content because of switching between skeleton and real content should be ok.
so I believe you need to set a placeholder for each element with a similar size
is that it?
I guess so.

It's probably low priority on the list anyway. I just checked pipa, they load everything at once, and still it is many times better score than us :joy:

<https://auctions.pipa.be/de/auction/2024-03-ad-fortuin-nl>
lol

For UX, skeleton is way better than a blank screen, for sure. It's about giving feedback for the user that content is being loaded, and the animation makes it seem faster than it is with a blank screen
I mean, user will never see blank screen
This is about content that is not visible in any way. We can load in the skeleton in 1 frame so user will never see this while scrolling :slightly_smiling_face:
if the users opens the page and quickly scrolls, it's possible, isn't it?

I am thinking about these cases where we have 100 lots on one page. Actually I guess the standard web way would be to lazy load the content anyway. So as user scrolls down, the scrollbar gets longer. That's how every mobile website seems to do it.
yes. as long as you inform the user that content is being loaded, that's ok
two skeletons while it loads, and it's more than enough

Hi @[Leticia]

we would like to differentiate here between four different "auction" types:

1. Online
2. Onlive
3. Live - this type does not include auction mechanisms but a date and time when it takes place. It opens the option to us to offer customers the presentation of collections on our websites
4. Open Sale - this type does not include auction mechanisms and no date and time, it is the option to choose when we want to show a bundle of horses on our websites with not time frame of sale
3. and 4. we will seldomly use but we want to include it already now to have it.

It should be possible to switch between the auction types as long the auction did not start (!)

When switching the auction types the system shall ask with pop up or similar if we really want to do so and then add or remove all the necessary fields that are additionally needed or not longer needed.

In a second step the system shall recognize which of the new fields are now mandatory for this auction type and should only allow final saving and switching the type when all necessary fields are filled out.

So its kind of a two-steps-change involved.

For ONLIVE auctions we do need the fields from second screenshot including the streaming pictures. The streaming pictures should always be by default with standard H24 images and can then be exchanged if wished. We also like to have the streaming keys included. They are empty first and after saving the auction the system shall generate and show them in seperate fields. Each field should have a copy button next to it.

I am not sure but did you already create the auctioneer page? (4th screenshot) If not, we need it please. It is the screen for the auctioneer where he can see the last five bids, the amount and name and country of the person that did the bid. If you need additional screenshots here please let me know

We do also need the reload users browser button from third screenshot
<https://trello.com/c/AZnM7pu3/27-changes-auction-settings-admin>
We do also need this part for fees, insurance and terms again where we can assign a term specific to a lot type and its insurance fee for Online and Onlive auctions

Independent of the auction type we need the option to upload a document or picture to the auction that is then shown at each lot. We need to give it a name too.

As often the customers publish horses when the veterinarian documents are not ready. To avoid questions of horse buyers when veterinarian documents are available they upload then an information file for each horse in the veterinarian part (see attachment) that states when everything is available and this is annoying to upload the same file to each horse. In addition it falsifies our analytics concerning the veterinarian viewers as all users who looked at this info sheet and then on the real veterinarian documents are mixed up and we can not identify the real interested people. As we need to delete then this file and upload the real documents

Hi @[Leticia]

please find attached a draft for the design of the lot layout which we want to do in a generic way.

At first the template is empty and one has to decide if the area should be with one column or two columns. We can add multiple areas below with the +add button and we can switch vertically the order.
In the case of two columns per area we need to decide which element is shown first (Marked with 1) and which second (marked with 2) below the first element for the mobile view. By changing 1 and 2 of the two columns the order is defined.

In the second step we can add the elements per area. Each element has its fix size. So e.g. Image and pedigree need to have full width. In case one wants to put it in to a two-column area system should not allow it and show a failure message.

In the third step we can give the area a name and the option to be a dropdown in frontend or static. Therewith we are able to customize the names too.

I am not sure if the three steps should be below each other on the right site of the screen or if the system shows only by clicking in to the relevant area which step/selection is required next.

If anything is not clear please let me know

The following fonts are the best web safe fonts for HTML and CSS:
• Arial (sans-serif)
• Verdana (sans-serif)
• Tahoma (sans-serif)
• Trebuchet MS (sans-serif)
• Times New Roman (serif)
• Georgia (serif)
• Garamond (serif)
• Courier New (monospace)
• Brush Script MT (cursive)

"He says it's not a big deal and user won't notice" This is a dev talking lol

if you load the fonts async, even last, leaving a fallback, you can a good font without jeopardizing load times. the fallback will handle the text until the font is loaded.

the right font for each case is also important, it's not just a pretty font.

@[Leticia] The news feature in the new project is designed as follows: The Super Admin has the authority to enable or disable the "News Site" feature for each child site. Once enabled, each child site can publish its own news, which will then be visible on that child site. There must be an option to toggle the visibility of the news on or off.

Additionally, there should be a dedicated page on the parent site where the Super Admin can manage news visibility for the parent site. This includes deciding which news from the child sites should be displayed on the parent site and which should not. The configuration settings should offer the flexibility to either show all news from a child site or only specific selected news items.

BUT, the parent site can add also his own news that are just seen on parent site!

for the individual lot page we need the following parts included

View bids - Shows a list of all bids that are done on that specific lot (maybe if bidding did not started show information box) and has an export function

Reset lot - Not needed

Generate QR code - Opens the explorer to save a png with the qr code of that lot

Users in wishlist - Opens a list with all users that have set this lot to their wishlist or as preference (the name is not so nice, maybe we do something else like only Wishlist or wishlist users?) Export should also be possible

Edit lot winner flag - Opens menu to change winning flag after auction closed (maybe if bidding not finished show info box)

View vet users - to be generic this should be called View document users or document requests, it shall open a list of all users with their names and mail adresses and when (date and time) and what kind of document (in the horse case: protocol or xrays) the user rquested. Hi everyone, please I want to direct your attention to this component because it is good to explain the problems in the future we should avoid.

<https://sporthorses24.com/developers/katon/-/blob/main/admin-frontend/components/site/Team.vue>

You can see here that this component has the precise appearance of the teams tab in the admin with tailwind classes. But it also contains the logic to determine what happens when a button is pressed etc. Then it contains further logic to emit events, which is passed to a <https://sporthorses24.com/developers/katon/-/blob/main/admin-frontend/components/site/TeamList.vue|TeamList.vue>, which again contains both tailwind and logic.

What this means is that in the end, it will be really hard to work with the logic of the teams tab in the admin. Because there will be different components, that all contain logic and communicate with each other. So if you want to change a behavior, it can get confusing fast. And it may also happen that if you try to change the appearance, you accidentally change the behavior, as it's all in the same file. Or the other way around.

I am currently refactoring these components and improving the structure to have pure presentational components, and all the logic in composables. This will also allow us to test the appearance of the component in histoire. I just wanted to share this example to make it clear why a good structure on the client is so important.
This kind of thing is why I was apprehensive about classes. Just want to make it clear that props are immutable and should never be modified.

Hi, @[Christian Bielert]
Actually, I heard about inertia.js but I don't have experience on using it.
So I investigated about inertia.js in details and found some Pros and Cons.

This is the comparison result from ChatGPT.
```Both of the stacks you mentioned, Laravel API + Nuxt.js and Laravel + Inertia.js, are valid ways to build a modern web application, but they each have their own strengths and potential drawbacks. Here are some pros and cons to consider.

**Laravel API + Nuxt.js**

*Pros:*

1. *Scalability*: This approach suits large-scale applications because it decouples the frontend from the backend. This division allows the frontend and backend to scale independently.

2. *Modularity*: Also, because of the decoupling, the development team can work on the frontend and backend separately, which may increase development efficiency.

3. *Flexibility*: Nuxt.js can be used as a static site generator or to build server-side rendering (SSR) applications, which can improve SEO.

4. *Language*: By using a fully decoupled approach, frontend developers can work entirely in JavaScript.

*Cons:*

1. *Complexity*: This approach might be a bit overkill for small projects. 

2. *More requests to server*: Since the client and server are separate, more requests might need to be made between them, which could affect performance.


**Laravel + Inertia.js**

*Pros:*

1. *Simplicity*: Inertia.js allows you to create fully client-side rendered, single-page apps, without much of the complexity that typically comes with this architecture.

2. *Shared State*: Because Inertia.js operates within the context of a server-side framework, it's possible to share state directly from your server-side controllers into your JavaScript well.

3. *Reduced API calls*: Not having to perform API requests for data could lead to a more seamless user experience.

4. *Full-stack approach*: Laravel + Inertia.js is the way to go if you are a solo developer or small team and want to use one single technology for full stack developing.

*Cons:*

1. *Less Scalability*: Inertia.js is essentially a monolithic stack, which means that if your website receives a lot of traffic, scalability could be more difficult than with a decoupled architecture.

2. *Server-side dependence*: Inertia.js is heavily dependent on the server-side, restricting you to use Laravel (or another server-side framework) for handling many aspects of your application.

Remember that the best stack for you will depend on the specifics of your project, your familiarity with the technology, and what you're trying to accomplish.```
In a word, inertia.js is good for small projects and small teams because it uses one single technology for full stack developing.
And it's not good for scalability and maintenance.

However, Nuxt is good for scalability because the frontend and backend are developed separately, so the modularity is very good.
And in this way, we use APIs to communicate between frontend and backend, so it's easy to find issues and keep maintenance.

@[Thiago] As I understand it, in this case we are using classes as a replacement for composables. Do you think this is a good way?

@[Christian Bielert]
I left my own comments for your feedback.

Let me explain about benefit of using class model.
I will take an example in User model.

As you know, there are firstName and lastName fields in the user model, but we often need to use fullName.
In this case, we can simply define fullName accessor inside the class.
But if we define user model as interface, we need to make a helper to get fullName from User interface.
Am I right?
Yes, I get your point. I am just concerned about going too much into OOP model. Not all can be modeled well using model classes.

@[Christian Bielert]
Then, we will use classes in composables.
Using class is modern way in typescript.
We can use many class' good points than interface. Interface is just type in one word.
How about your thought?
If you say it is good, then it is fine by me.
I am a functional programmer so I have a different opinion, but what is important is that you say it will work well for you.

Well, actually, there is another benefit of using class model.
With class model, we can set default values for undefined fields.
For example, let's assume that there is an issue on the backend side, so it returns a user response which contains undefined lastName.
But in the fronend, we defined lastName as mandatory in the user interface.
In this case, there will be an issue on the frontend side too.

We can prevent this issue with class model by defining default values in the class contructor.
As you can see, I defined init function in the class constructor, and it initiates all variables with default value even if the real value is undefined.

So I think, it's better to use class for models which are related to backend models.

Hi.
Sorry for delaying my answer. I've just finished to check design of project and this is not small project.
By the way, given the complexity and performance expectations of the project, I'd still prefer Nuxt + Laravel API for admin as well as user sides.

Because fist, using the same tech stack across the whole project would streamline our processes and minimize integration issues. I suppose, this can reduces the coding effort and improves development speed.
And then as you know, Nuxt.js with Laravel API has strong built-in SEO capacities and high loading performance due to its server-side rendering. It is a perfect match for our high-performing web apps.

The importants thing is that Nuxt simplifies the overall development process with numerous modules, layouts, and middleware. It offers the good points of versatility in building complex and efficient web applications, exactly what our project requires.

Of course, Livewire + Vue 3 has its own advantages but the features of Nuxt go beyond and align better with our project's needs.
In one word, I prefer Nuxt + Larave api
However, this is just my proposition.
Thank you.
Thank you for sharing your opinion.
@[Eric AKPLA] I know you explained it to me before, but can you please explain again also for @[Thiago] your reasons in favor of Livewire?

First, is the reason we don’t find reasonable to maintenant two different applications (Laravel, and Nuxt) for Admin part. it will accessed by admin users only. this just i though.

Livewire handles backend logic and frontend logic as well. so we do not have to code the API and also code the frontend to be using the api. Livewire maintain the communication between the back and front dynamically so it makes faster the coding flow.

By reading you, i think you miss understood. we will not be using Livewire + Vue3 for backend (Admin). We just need the Html and TailwindCss so we can use it to integrate using Laravel template engine Blade. Livewire uses Blade as template and AlpineJs for javascript actions.

in the call today with @[Christian Bielert] i was saying as he requested to have component Stories, instead of doing Just Html and TailwindCss @[Thiago] can be using VueJs for the component presentation.

The Ideal would be to use do the templates using Html + TailwindCss + AlpineJs (for dynamic actions like, hide, show etc).

Also the Admin is the central part of the project that uses Laravel Tenancy for to manage child sites informations.  And tenancy has its conventions. maintaining the state with one stack (Livewire PHP) would be fine instead of adding another layer of Nuxt.

This is why we think Livewire would be good for just the Admin

> Livewire handles backend logic and frontend logic as well. so we do not have to code the API and also code the frontend to be using the api. Livewire maintain the communication between the back and front dynamically so it makes faster the coding flow.
In my view I don't agree completely with this point. Because what you are saying is that you think, mixing together the presentation of the UI, together with the logic of the server, will make a faster coding flow. In my experience this is only true if everything, UI and logic, is built by the same developer. And it is also only true for building it the first time. If later we want to maintain the code and make changes, in my opinion this solution will be worse.

After considering the different viewpoints on using Livewire or Nuxt.js for our multi-tenant SaaS project, I would like to share my thoughts.
Personally, I am open to using either technology. My initial leaning towards Livewire was driven by its seamless integration with Laravel, which facilitates a cohesive interaction between the UI and backend. This synergy in the tech stack is particularly beneficial for component management.

However, I am also aware of the benefits offered by Nuxt.js, notably better flexibility and a distinct separation between UI and backend, which could simplify long-term maintenance.

My primary challenge at the moment is managing the switch between two tenants (children sites) during the same admin user session. We currently use the Hyn Tenancy package for tenant creation and management, and the admin has the ability to switch between different tenants and even the parent site for operations like auction creation, lot management, etc. We have relied heavily on session data to manage this effectively and securely, which was an additional reason for favoring Livewire.

With Nuxt.js, given the absence of native session management, we would need to find alternative methods for handling these switches. This is an aspect I have not fully explored yet, but it is clear that it will require some thinking to effectively address this need..
